messageBody:
On Fri, 19 Oct 2001, Robert Sartin wrote:
> We're converting to an automatic test detection system that marks test
> types and we plan to mark tests that require GUI code to run and only
> run them in environments that have the GUI.

Thanks for the suggestions and information (I was the poster of the
original question). I thought I would share my solution with the list.

I too ended up with a "test detection system" for a couple of reasons, the
main one being I cannot install virtual X displays on some of the systems
I work on. So then I tried to break apart my AllUnitTests suite into
GUI and non-GUI unit tests. However, I figured there was a better way
to solve this issue. Since the problem arises in junit itself, I thought
that would be a great place to test for the problem. The "solution" I came
up with is really simple:

package foo.applets.test;
import junit.framework.*;
/**
* Test suite for all unit tests for foo.applets package.
*/
public class AllTests { /* test suite */
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Applet tests");
// Add in non-GUI tests
suite.addTest(FormatterTest.suite());
// Only add in GUI tests if we are not running on
// a headless system (no display)
try {
// Use GUI stuff -- if it throws an Error
// ten we are running on a headless system
new foo.applets.Settings();
/*
* Settings is a class that has
* AWT Fonts and Colors etc. in it.
* On a headless system an Error will
* be thrown here.
*/
// Add in GUI tests
suite.addTest(QueryPanelTest.suite());
suite.addTest(FieldSelectionTest.suite());
...
} catch (Error e) {
// ok, we just won't add the GUI tests
System.out.println("Caught error " + e);
System.out.println("Ignoring GUI tests");
}
return suite;
}
}

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Without X-Display server (headless setup):

Caught error java.lang.InternalError: Can't connect to X11 window server using 'foo.bar.com:0.0' as the value of the DISPLAY variable.
Ignoring GUI tests
